docs.title: Welcome to the Cell Observatory
docs.text: Welcome to the Leiden Cell Observatory Documentation. This documentation provides information about the facility's microscopes, image analysis workflows, and image data management with OMERO.

docs.title: What's Inside
docs.text:
• Microscopes: Information about our available microscopes, including specifications, use cases, and booking procedures.
  • Image Analysis: Guidelines and workflows for analyzing microscopy data, including available software tools and best practices.
  • OMERO: Documentation on using OMERO for data storage, organization, and sharing.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
If you're new to the Cell Observatory:

  1. Check out the microscopes section to see what instruments are available
  2. Learn about data management in the OMERO section
  3. Explore our image analysis resources to plan your data analysis workflow

Need Help?

Contact facility staff for guidance on selecting the most appropriate systems and workflows for your experiments.

docs.title: For questions you can reach out to:
Contributing
docs.text:
This wiki is for all of us, so if you think something is missing, feel free to contribute.

For people at Leiden University you can join the Cell Observatory Github. Then we can give you permission to contribute.

Or if you prefer can you post your contribution on the Cell Observatory MS Teams website and it will be added here.

docs.title: Learning Resources
docs.text: This section provides a curated collection of external resources for bioimage analysis, training materials, and useful tools.

docs.title: Software and Tools Collections
docs.text: • Awesome Biological Image Analysis - A comprehensive list of software, tools, pipelines, and plugins for biological image analysis

docs.title: Learning Materials
docs.text:
• BiA-PoL blog - Blog with examples of image analysis pipelines
  • Introduction to Bioimage Analysis - Comprehensive guide to bioimage analysis
  • Bio-image Analysis Notebooks - Interactive notebooks for learning bioimage analysis

  • GloBIAS
  • Crick BioImage Analysis Symposium

docs.title: Image Analysis
docs.text: The Cell Observatory provides access to various image analysis tools and workflows. This section covers different software packages and approaches for analyzing microscopy data.

docs.title: Available Tools
docs.text:
• CellPose - Deep learning-based cell segmentation
  • CellProfiler - Pipeline-based image analysis
  • Fiji - ImageJ-based analysis platform
  • Ilastik - Interactive machine learning for image analysis
  • Micro-SAM - Segment Anything Model for microscopy
  • TrackMate - Object tracking in Fiji

docs.title: Environment Setup
docs.text: For Python-based tools, see our guide on setting up your Conda environment.

docs.title: Version Control
docs.text: Learn about using GitHub for managing your analysis scripts and workflows.

docs.title: Fiji
docs.text: Your content here

docs.title: writing Fiji macros
docs.text: writing your first macros's record your steps via recorder check reference here. for all functions

docs.title: writing more advanced scripts
docs.text: Using Jython, Groovy or Beanshell more complex scripts can be written.

docs.title: maintaining your scripts
docs.text: see GitHub page for info

docs.title: TrackMate
docs.text:
https://imagej.net/plugins/trackmate/ Getting started: https://imagej.net/plugins/trackmate/tutorials/getting-started

Fiji plugin to track objects e.g. cells, foci or single-molecules.

Basically consists of two steps. First segmentation/detection of objects then apply a tracking algorithm on this.

Segmentation of objects can be done through different methods e.g. spot detector, on a binary image, Stardist (nuclei), Cellpose, ilastik. For tracking also different algorithms are available.

Scriptable in Fiji. https://imagej.net/plugins/trackmate/scripting/scripting

Also tools available to apply same analysis on multiple images without writing a script. Trackmate batcher: https://forum.image.sc/t/new-version-of-the-trackmate-helper-v1-2-1-with-a-batcher-and-the-spt-metrics/68180

docs.title: Saving TrackMate projects
docs.text:
• TrackMate results can be saved as XML files containing all tracking data
  • You can open this again in Fiji via Plugins->Tracking->Load a TrackMate file
  • Trick for projecting tracks onto a different image: You can open the XML file in a text editor, then search for the image filename reference and modify it

docs.title: Key points to discuss:
docs.text:
• Integration with OMERO: How to store and retrieve TrackMate results in OMERO
  • Batch processing: Methods for applying the same tracking parameters across multiple images
  • Script examples: Basic Jython/Groovy scripts for automating TrackMate analysis
  • Export options: Different ways to export tracking results (CSV, ROIs, visualizations)
  • TrackMate parameters: Explanation of key tracking settings and when to adjust them

docs.title: Cellpose
docs.text:
https://cellpose.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

{.align-center}

install via conda 

conda create -n cellpose 
conda activate cellpose
pip install cellpose

with CUDA GPU: 

conda create -n cellpose pytorch=1.8.2 cudatoolkit=10.2 -c pytorch-lts
conda activate cellpose
pip install cellpose

run gui via command line: cellpose

docs.title: Cell Profiler
docs.text: Your content here

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To be able to handle multiple software environments on a system use of conda is adviced. Different software packages require different versions of Python and other dependencies. Conda allows to create isolated environments on your computer. It is adviced to always work within an conda environment and not in the base environment.

A detailed instruction how to setup conda can be found here.

https://biapol.github.io/blog/mara_lampert/getting_started_with_miniforge_and_python/readme.html#ref-miniforge-python

docs.title: Working with Git(hub)
docs.text:
To use git

Do you want to learn all the details on Git: https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2

Useful tools: - Github Desktop Although git can be used from the command line a visual overview of your repositories on your computer can be helpful to keep overview of your repositories, local changes that are not committed to github. - VS code

docs.title: Managing your Fiji scripts with Github
docs.text:
• Create a folder in you Fiji /scripts folder e.g. 'My-Scripts"
  • This folder will show up as a separate menu in Fiji
  • Create a github repository at github.com e.g. name it "My Fiji scripts"
  • Use github desktop or git command line ...

{.align-center}

docs.title: Cell Observatory Github
docs.text: github.com/Leiden-Cell-Observatory

docs.title: ilastik
docs.text:
Useful tool to that allows to quickly train a pixel and/or object classifier with sparse annotation on your images.

Can be installed here:

After training the model can be used in Fiji to apply to a large number of images in batch. It can even be used in TrackMate to track segmented objects.

Also can be combined with CellProfiler.

docs.title: Segmentation with micro-sam
docs.text:
Segment Anything for Microscopy or micro-sam is a tool to enable automatic and interactive segmentation of microscopy data.

In order to use the micro-sam toolkit it is advisble to use a computer with a decent GPU.

micro-sam can be use to interactively segment images (2D, 3D, time series) in napari. It can also be used to fine-tune the Segment Anything model to allow for automatic instance segmentation of your images.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
It is adviced to install micro-sam in a conda environment. Check here to install conda.

conda env create --file environment.yml -n micro-sam
conda install -c conda-forge micro_sam

To open the micro-sam plugins:

napari

docs.title: finetuning a model for automatic segmentation
What image analysis tool should I use?
Computing Resources
docs.text: The Cell Observatory provides access to various computing resources to support your imaging and analysis workflows.

docs.title: Available Resources
docs.text:
• High Performance Computing (HPC) - Access to the university's HPC cluster for intensive analysis tasks
  • Workstations - Information about our local workstations and their capabilities

docs.title: When to Use What
docs.text:
• Use local workstations for:
  • Interactive analysis sessions
  • Small to medium datasets

  • Real-time visualization needs

  • Use HPC for:

  • Large-scale batch processing
  • Deep learning tasks
  • Computing-intensive analysis pipelines

docs.title: High-Performance Computing (Alice)
docs.text: This section covers the usage of the Alice HPC cluster for image analysis.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Alice cluster provides high-performance computing capabilities for more demanding image analysis tasks.

More on Alice: Alice Wiki

docs.title: Microscopes
docs.text: The Cell Observatory houses several state-of-the-art microscopes for various imaging applications.

docs.title: Available Systems
docs.text:
• Nikon A1 - Confocal microscope system
  • DIC Microscopy - Differential Interference Contrast microscopy
  • IBL Microscopes - Overview of IBL microscopy systems
  • Widefield Observer - Widefield fluorescence microscope

docs.title: Choosing a Microscope
docs.text:
Consider these factors when selecting a microscope:

  • Sample type and preparation
  • Required resolution
  • Fluorescence vs. transmitted light
  • Live imaging needs
  • Speed requirements
  • Sample sensitivity

Please consult with the facility staff for guidance on selecting the most appropriate system for your experiments.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The A1 is a fluorescence microscope that uses LED lights for fluorophore excitation instead of a traditional white light source. This unique feature provides precise control over excitation wavelengths and reduces photobleaching.

docs.title: Excitation Control
docs.text:
• The LED lights can be turned on/off using the control wheel on the right side of the microscope
  • Brightness can be adjusted by moving the wheel up (more intense) or down (less intense)
  • Press the wheel to toggle the fluorescence on/off

docs.title: Filter Positions
docs.text:
The filter wheel has multiple positions for different fluorescence channels:

  1. Position 1: Brightfield
  2. Position 2: Green fluorescence
  3. Position 3: Red fluorescence
  4. Position 4: Blue fluorescence

docs.title: Condenser Settings
docs.text:
Located below the stage, the condenser wheel offers several imaging modes:

  • Phase Contrast Settings:
  • Ph1: For 10x magnification
  • Ph2: For 20x and 40x magnification
  • Ph3: For 100x magnification
  • D: Darkfield imaging mode

docs.title: Light Control
docs.text:
• Power switch: Located on the left side behind the focus wheel
  • Intensity adjustment: Use the wheel below the focus wheel on the left side

docs.title: Transmitted Light Blocking
docs.text: When combining brightfield with fluorescence imaging: 1. Locate the black bar block 2. Remove and invert it so the black bar blocks the transmitted light 3. The diffuser end will stick out when properly positioned

docs.title: Image Acquisition
docs.text:
Once your sample is in focus and imaging parameters are set, proceed to image acquisition using the computer system.

For optimal results when combining fluorescence and brightfield imaging, ensure proper blocking of transmitted light to prevent interference with fluorescence signals.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Start with lower LED intensities and adjust as needed
  2. Verify correct phase contrast settings for your objective
  3. Ensure proper light blocking when combining imaging modes
  4. Focus your sample using brightfield before switching to fluorescence

docs.title: Left Side Controls
docs.text: - Focus Wheel: Main focus control (green) - Focus Mode Switch: Toggle between coarse and fine focus (dark blue) - Sample Exchange Buttons: (cyan) - Lower stage for sample removal - Return to previous focus height - Note: Disable this feature when sample heights vary to prevent objective crashes - Condenser Focus Wheel: (purple) Used for Köhler illumination - Ocular Light Block: Red pin that blocks light to oculars when pushed in

docs.title: Right Side Controls
docs.text: - Focus Controls: - Focus wheel (green oval) - Sample loading positions (cyan) - Fine/Course focus switch (dark blue) - Light Controls: - Power switch with intensity control (green) - Light Manager buttons for 3200K illumination - Stage Control: XY positioning (yellow) - Filter Controls: - Neutral density filter wheels (red) - Fluorescence light path adjustments (orange) - Beam path switch (purple)

docs.title: Light Manager Features
docs.text:
• Left button: Toggle between 3200K and manual control
  • Right button: Switch between brightfield and fluorescence
  • Neutral density filters available for intensity reduction while maintaining color balance

docs.title: Light Path Controls
docs.text: The beam path switch offers three positions: 1. Oculars only 2. Camera only 3. 50/50 split (enables simultaneous viewing and live imaging)

docs.title: Filter Wheel Positions
docs.text: 1. UV (DAPI, Hoechst) 2. CFP and cyan dyes 3. GFP, FITC, green fluorescent dyes 4. YFP 5. TRITC, rhodamine, propidium iodide, mCherry 6. Transmitted light (with/without DIC) 7. Empty 8. Empty

docs.title: Condenser Settings
docs.text:
• I/BF: Brightfield and DIC
  • 2, 3: Phase contrast or DIC (II and III)
  • D: Darkfield (20x objectives and lower)
  • Adjustable condenser diaphragm for contrast/resolution control

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text: 1. Login to the system 2. Start AxioVision 3. Configure storage settings: - Set autosave location - Choose file format (ZVI recommended for full metadata) 4. Configure naming conventions for single and multi-dimensional acquisitions

docs.title: Basic Imaging
docs.text:
1. Select correct objective in microscope menu 2. Focus on sample 3. Switch to live view 4. Adjust camera settings: - Set exposure time (manual or auto) - Use white balance for color correction - Configure display settings (linear/min/max/best fit)

Never modify gamma settings during quantitative imaging as it affects intensity relationships.

docs.title: Multidimensional Acquisition
docs.text: - Predefined channel settings available - Individual exposure times per channel - Automatic overlay generation

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts
docs.text: - Numpad 1-7: Filter wheel positions and shutter control - Spacebar/F2: Take snapshot - Each numpad number corresponds to specific filter settings: 1. All shutters closed 2. UV (DAPI) 3. CFP 4. GFP/FITC 5. YFP 6. TRITC/mCherry 7. Transmitted light

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Fluorescence Lamp Usage
  2. Turn off when finished if no users within 30 minutes
  3. Allow 30-minute cooldown period

  4. Limited bulb lifetime - avoid unnecessary use

  5. Image Quality

  6. Use appropriate phase contrast settings
  7. Optimize DIC prism position for best contrast

  8. Consider neutral density filters for bright samples

  9. Data Management

  10. Store data on designated data disk
  11. Create personal folder for organization
  12. Use ZVI format to preserve metadata

For optimal image quality, ensure proper Köhler illumination setup and appropriate condenser settings for your chosen imaging mode.

docs.title: Zeiss Stereo Zoom V16
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.31b - Capabilities: - Stereo fluorescence microscope - Automated focus, zoom, and stage control - Digital color camera - Multiple filters (GFP, DSR, YFP, CFP, CY5, Alexa 405) - Automated stage and incubation options - Book Stereo Sylvius

docs.title: Zeiss V8
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.31a - Capabilities: - Stereo light microscope - Manual focus and zoom control - Bresser digital color camera - Book Stereo Sylvius

docs.title: Stereo Fluorescence Microscope
docs.text:
• Location: Cell Observatory GW2.28
  • Capabilities:
  • Multiple filters (GFP, DSR, YFP, CFP, CY5, Alexa 405)
  • Leica DFC 345FX camera
  • Book Stereo Gorlaeus

docs.title: Zeiss Observer
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.31a - Features: - Widefield fluorescence with Colibri system - DAPI, GFP, and mCherry filters - Automated stage - Hamamatsu EMCCD - Multi-well imaging capability - Book Observer - Detailed Multi-well Imaging Guide

docs.title: Zeiss Axioscope A1
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.31a - Features: - Widefield fluorescence with Colibri system - DAPI, GFP, and mCherry filters - Book Widefield

docs.title: Zeiss Imager M2 (DIC)
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.35 - Features: - Upright fluorescence microscope - DIC optics - Zeiss AxioCam MRc 5 digital color camera - Filter blocks for DAPI, CFP, GFP, YFP, mCherry, DIC - Custom filter options available (consult Gerda or Joost) - Book Widefield - Detailed DIC Manual

docs.title: Nikon A1
docs.text:
• Location: Listed under Nikon Systems
  • Features:
  • LED-based fluorescence excitation
  • Multiple fluorescence channels
  • Phase contrast capability
  • Detailed A1 Manual

docs.title: Zeiss Airyscan 900
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.32 - Specifications: - Inverted confocal laser scanning microscope - Temperature-controlled incubation - Automated stage control - Three fluorescence detector channels - One transmitted light channel - Laser lines: 405, 488, 543, and 633 nm - Book Confocal - View Instructions

docs.title: Zeiss LSM5 Exciter / AxioImager
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.32 - Specifications: - Upright confocal laser scanning microscope - Two fluorescence detector channels - One transmitted light channel - Laser lines: 458, 488, 514, 543, and 633 nm - Book Confocal - View Instructions

docs.title: Leica TCS SPE
docs.text: - Location: Cell Observatory GW 2.30a - Specifications: - Inverted confocal laser scanning microscope - One spectral detector channel for fluorescence - One transmitted light channel - Laser lines: 488, 532, and 633 nm - Book Confocal - View Instructions (Dutch)

docs.title: Leica SP8
docs.text: - Location: Cell Observatory GW 2.30a - Specifications: - Inverted confocal laser scanning microscope - Three spectral detector channels (2 PMT, one GASP) - One transmitted light channel - Laser lines: 405, 488, 532, and 633 nm - Book Confocal - View Instructions

docs.title: JEOL SEM 7600
docs.text: - Location: Sylvius, Rm. 6.5.34 - Features: - Conventional high vacuum scanning electron microscope - Digital imaging - Cryo-unit for freezing, coating and imaging - EDS for elemental analysis - Book SEM

docs.title: JEOL TEM 1400+
docs.text: - Location: Cell Observatory GW2.24a - Specifications: - 120 kV transmission electron microscope - Book TEM

docs.title: LEICA DM6000 (VAST)
docs.text:
- Location: Cell Observatory GW2.28 - Specifications: - Leica SL confocal CTR 6000 - DFC 450C camera - VAST BioImager + LP Sampler (Union Biometrica) - Laser lines: - Ar: 457, 488, 515 nm - HeNe: 543, 633 nm - Book VAST

Contact facility staff for training before first use of any microscope system.

docs.title: Multi-well Imaging Setup
docs.text: This guide covers the setup process for multi-well imaging using the Zeiss Observer microscope with Zen-blue software.

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text:
1. Launch Zen-blue software
  2. Calibrate the stage
  3. Navigate to acquisition tab
  4. Activate the tiles module

docs.title: Sample Carrier Configuration
docs.text:
1. In the tiles menu, select "Sample Carrier"
  2. Choose your desired carrier type
  3. Use Smart Setup to configure imaging conditions

    At least one channel must be set up for carrier calibration

docs.title: Calibration Process
docs.text:
1. Stage Calibration
  2. Option to calibrate using transmitted light (recommended)

  3. Choose between re-calibrating or continuing with existing calibration

  4. Calibration Points

  5. Select calibration method (7 points recommended)
  6. Position points with high accuracy
  7. More points generally yield better results

docs.title: Region Setup Options
docs.text:
1. Contour Method

  2. Draw regions manually for imaging

  3. Predefined Method

  4. Click on slide to add region

  5. Use plus button to add setup region

  6. Carrier Method

  7. Set fill factor for coverage
  8. Configure columns/rows for custom layout
  9. Click create to generate tile regions

docs.title: Position Setup Options
docs.text:
1. Location Method
  2. Manual point placement

  3. Click to add specific points

  4. Array Method

  5. Add multiple points in random or grid pattern

  6. Draw regions to define point distribution area

  7. Carrier Method

  8. Add regions (columns/rows) in each well

docs.title: Focus Settings
docs.text:
1. Access Support Point Editor (circle with dot icon above calibrate button)
  2. Add support points for focus shift:
  3. Manual addition via plus button
  4. Add one per container
  5. Set row/column distribution
  6. Adjust point positions as needed

docs.title: Final Steps
docs.text:
1. Verify all tile regions
  2. Review support point positions
  3. Confirm settings before starting acquisition

For optimal results, carefully verify focus points and tile regions before starting a long acquisition sequence.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use transmitted light for initial calibration when possible
  2. Add sufficient support points to maintain focus across the sample
  3. Verify all settings before starting long acquisitions
  4. Consider sample characteristics when choosing imaging regions

docs.title: OMERO
docs.text: OMERO (Open Microscopy Environment Remote Objects) is our primary platform for microscopy data management, storage, and sharing.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Secure data storage
  • Metadata management
  • Image viewing and basic analysis
  • Collaboration tools
  • API access for automated workflows

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Getting Started Guide - Set up your account and learn the basics
  2. Importing Data - Learn how to upload your microscopy data
  3. Downloading Data - Access your data from OMERO
  4. Analysis in OMERO - Use OMERO's analysis capabilities

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always include experimental metadata when importing
  • Use consistent naming conventions
  • Organize data into projects and datasets
  • Add tags and annotations for better searchability
  • Regular backup of analysis workflows

docs.title: Data Analysis with OMERO
docs.text: There are different ways you can interact with data in OMERO.

docs.title: Installation Steps
docs.text:
1. Install Fiji
  2. Update Fiji and ensure all plugins are up to date (Help > Update)
  3. If you get errors, repeat the update (the updater might need multiple attempts)
  4. After seeing "Updated successfully. Please restart ImageJ!" message, restart Fiji
  1. After restart, update again and click "Manage Update Sites"
  1. Enable these required sites:
  2. Fiji legacy
  3. 3D Image suite
  4. ImageScience
  5. Leiden University
  1. Click Close and Apply Changes
  2. Restart Fiji
  3. Install the Simple OMERO Client:
  4. Download from GitHub releases
  5. Place in Fiji's plugins folder
  6. Restart Fiji

docs.title: Manual Single Image Analysis
docs.text:
1. Open OMERO connection:
  2. Go to Plugins > OMERO > Connect to OMERO
  3. Login with ULCN credentials

  4. OMERO insight connected to Fiji will open

  5. Access your image:

  6. Locate image in left sidebar or thumbnails

  7. Double-click to open

  8. Configure BioFormats Import:

  9. Adjust settings as needed
  10. Click OK
  11. Wait for loading (may take several minutes, no progress bar visible)

docs.title: Manual Dataset Analysis
docs.text:
1. Launch dataset opener:
  2. Go to Plugins > LeidenUniv > OMERO > Open OMERO dataset

  3. Enter login credentials:

  4. Select dataset:

  5. Choose group, user, project, and dataset

  6. Click OK

  7. Monitor progress:

  8. Watch log window for loading progress

docs.title: Automated Dataset Analysis
docs.text:
1. Start automated analysis:
  2. Go to Plugins > LeidenUniv > OMERO > Run OMERO plugin

  3. Choose plugin from menu:

  4. Provide credentials:

  5. Select dataset:

  6. View results:

  7. Results attach to image/dataset automatically

If you need a plugin that isn't available, contact J.J. (Joost) Willemse for assistance.

docs.title: Quick Downloads
docs.text:
• Use download button (yellow) on OMERO web interface:
  • Choose export format:

docs.title: Large Dataset Downloads
docs.text:
The web browser downloads timeout after 1 minute (60s). For large datasets, use OMERO.insight client.

  1. In OMERO.insight:
  2. Navigate to your dataset

  3. Click download button

  4. Select export format:

  5. Download proceeds in background

docs.title: Server Scripts
docs.text:
Access server scripts through the web interface:

For new script development, contact Willemse, J.J. (Joost).

docs.title: Important Notes
docs.text:
• Server is optimized for storage, not computation
  • Scripts may take significant time to process
  • All scripts must be tested on test-server first
  • DO NOT develop or test scripts without admin consultation

docs.title: Downloading and Exporting Data
docs.text: This section covers how to download and export data from OMERO.

docs.title: Quick Downloads
docs.text:
Access downloads through the OMERO web interface:

  1. Locate your data

  2. Click the download button (marked yellow)

  3. Choose export format:

  4. Original files
  5. OME-TIFF format
  6. JPEG format
  7. PNG format
  8. TIFF format

docs.title: Browser Timeout Limitation
docs.text: Web browser downloads automatically disconnect after 1 minute (60s). For large datasets, use OMERO.insight instead.

docs.title: Large Dataset Downloads
docs.text:
1. Launch and log into OMERO.insight
  2. Navigate to your dataset

  3. Click the download button

  4. Select export format:

Downloads proceed in the background - no progress bar is shown, but the process remains active.

docs.title: Standard Formats
docs.text:
• Original Format: Exact copy of uploaded file
  • OME-TIFF: Standard microscopy format
  • JPEG/PNG: For presentations/publications
  • TIFF: For analysis software

docs.title: Format Selection
docs.text: Choose based on intended use: - Analysis: Original or OME-TIFF - Presentation: JPEG/PNG - Archive: Original format

docs.title: Dataset Export
docs.text:
1. Select entire dataset
  2. Choose export format
  3. Select destination folder
  4. Wait for background process

docs.title: Project Export
docs.text:
• Can export entire projects
  • Maintains folder structure
  • Includes annotations if selected

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Planning Downloads
  2. Estimate data size
  3. Choose appropriate method

  4. Verify storage space

  5. Organization

  6. Maintain folder structure
  7. Use meaningful names

  8. Document downloads

  9. Verification

  10. Check file integrity
  11. Verify metadata retention
  12. Test sample files

docs.title: Registration Process
docs.text:
To access OMERO, you need to be approved in the ULCN system. Please follow these steps:

  1. Fill in the registration form
  2. Wait for approval from an OMERO admin
  3. Complete your first login (see below)

docs.title: OMERO Administrators
docs.text: Contact any of the following administrators for registration and OMERO-related questions: - Joost Willemse (IBL) - Sylvia Le Dévédec (LACDR)

docs.title: First Time Login
docs.text:
Important: Login must be done within the university network (LAN or WLAN)

  1. Visit OMERO Web Portal
  2. Login using your ULCN credentials
  3. Logout after successful login
  4. Inform your admin that you've completed the first login
  5. Wait for confirmation that you've been assigned to the correct group before importing data

docs.title: Remote Access
docs.text:
You can access OMERO from outside the university through several methods:

  1. Remote Desktop Connection
  2. Request access via Remote Desktop Form

  3. Connect to your university PC

  4. Remote Workplace

  5. Access through Remote Workplace Portal

  6. EduVPN

  7. Set up EduVPN for a secure connection

docs.title: OMERO.insight Installation
docs.text:
For uploading data from your computer or downloading large datasets, you'll need OMERO.insight:

  1. Download OMERO.insight
  2. Request installation:
  3. Submit a software request, or
  4. Request a semi-managed account

docs.title: Configuring OMERO.insight
docs.text:
1. Start OMERO.insight
  2. Click the tool icon
  3. Add the Leiden server:
  4. Press the + sign
  5. Enter server address: omero.services.universiteitleiden.nl
  6. Click Apply
  7. Login using your ULCN credentials

After your account is set up, you'll be able to see all data in your assigned group. Contact your OMERO admin if you need access to additional groups.

docs.title: Importing Data into OMERO
docs.text: This section covers the general procedures for importing data into OMERO at the Leiden Cell Observatory.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: OMERO.insight is the primary tool for importing data. This client is: - Pre-installed on all microscope PC's - Available for download on computers (Windows, Mac, Linux) https://www.openmicroscopy.org/omero/downloads/

docs.title: Basic Import Workflow
docs.text:
1. Prepare Your Data
  2. Organize files in a clear structure
  3. Consider project/dataset organization

  4. Prepare any metadata you want to include

  5. Launch OMERO.insight

  6. Connect to server: omero.services.universiteitleiden.nl
  7. Login with ULCN credentials

  8. Navigate to your group/project space

  9. Import Process

  10. Use File > Import or the import icon
  11. Select files for import
  12. Choose or create projects/datasets
  13. Add any tags or annotations
  14. Review and start import

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text: OMERO uses a two-level organization system: - Projects (top level) - Datasets (within projects)

docs.title: Recommended Folder Structure
docs.text:
When preparing data for import:

✅ Recommended Structure:
Project folder (selected folder)
├── subfolder 1
│   └── image 1, etc.
└── subfolder 2
    └── image 1, etc.

❌ Avoid:
Project folder
└── subfolder 1
    ├── subfolder I (experiment 1)
    └── subfolder II (experiment 2)

Planning Your Import

Before starting a large import: 1. Plan your project/dataset structure 2. Prepare metadata if needed 3. Consider file type specific requirements

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• For specific file types, see Microscope Files
  • For high-content screening data, check HCS Data
  • To add metadata, refer to Metadata Annotations

docs.title: High-Content Screening (HCS) Data
docs.text: This guide covers importing and managing high-content screening data in OMERO.

docs.title: HCS Data Structure
docs.text: OMERO supports the hierarchical organization of HCS data: - Plate - Well - Field - Channel - Timepoint

docs.title: Metadata Requirements
docs.text:
• Plate layout information
  • Well naming conventions
  • Experimental conditions
  • Treatment annotations

docs.title: File Organization
docs.text:
1. Maintain original plate structure
  2. Keep metadata files with raw data
  3. Document plate layouts
  4. Preserve screen/plate relationships

docs.title: Before Import
docs.text:
1. Organize Data
  2. Group plates by screen
  3. Maintain consistent naming

  4. Document experimental conditions

  5. Prepare Metadata

  6. Create plate layouts
  7. Document treatments
  8. Note quality control metrics

docs.title: During Import
docs.text:
1. Verify Plate Structure
  2. Check well detection
  3. Confirm field count

  4. Validate channel settings

  5. Add Annotations

  6. Screen information
  7. Experimental conditions
  8. Quality metrics

docs.title: After Import
docs.text:
1. Validate Data
  2. Check plate layout
  3. Verify well positions

  4. Confirm metadata

  5. Organization

  6. Group related plates
  7. Add screen-level annotations
  8. Link to protocols

docs.title: Metadata Annotations
docs.text: This guide covers how to add and manage metadata annotations in OMERO.

docs.title: Types of Metadata
docs.text: OMERO supports several types of metadata annotations: - Tags - Key-value pairs - Comments - Files - Ratings

docs.title: Basic Annotations
docs.text:
1. Tags
  2. Use consistent naming
  3. Create tag sets for organization

  4. Apply multiple tags as needed

  5. Key-Value Pairs

  6. Experimental conditions
  7. Instrument settings

  8. Sample information

  9. Comments

  10. Observation notes
  11. Quality assessments
  12. Processing steps

docs.title: File Annotations
docs.text:
• Attach protocols
  • Include analysis scripts
  • Link to supplementary data

docs.title: Structured Annotations
docs.text:
• Create custom forms
  • Define metadata templates
  • Use consistent formats

docs.title: Organization
docs.text:
1. Tag Management
  2. Use hierarchical tag sets
  3. Maintain consistent naming

  4. Document tag meanings

  5. Key-Value Structure

  6. Use standard formats
  7. Define required fields
  8. Document units

docs.title: Workflow Integration
docs.text:
1. During Import
  2. Add essential metadata
  3. Apply standard tags

  4. Include basic annotations

  5. Post-Import

  6. Add analysis results
  7. Update with findings
  8. Link related data

docs.title: Microscope Files
docs.text: This guide covers importing specific microscope file formats into OMERO.

docs.title: Supported File Types
docs.text: OMERO supports most common microscopy formats including: - Nikon ND2 - Zeiss LSM and CZI - Leica LIF - TIFF series - And many more through Bio-Formats

docs.title: Nikon ND2 Files
docs.text:
• Keep associated metadata files together
  • Import complete ND2 files, not exported TIFFs
  • Verify all channels are preserved

docs.title: Zeiss Files
docs.text:
• For LSM files, ensure metadata is preserved
  • With CZI files, check all scenes are included
  • Maintain folder structure for multi-file datasets

docs.title: TIFF Series
docs.text:
• Keep sequential naming intact
  • Include any companion metadata files
  • Maintain channel order and naming

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Verify File Completeness
  2. Include all necessary metadata files
  3. Keep original file structure

  4. Don't split multi-dimensional data

  5. Check Before Import

  6. Verify file readability
  7. Ensure all dimensions are preserved

  8. Check channel names and metadata

  9. After Import

  10. Verify all dimensions imported correctly
  11. Check channel settings
  12. Confirm metadata transferred properly

docs.title: Publishing
docs.text: This section provides guidelines and resources for publishing your microscopy data and analysis.

docs.title: Publishing Guidelines
docs.text:
• Methods - Templates and guidelines for writing microscopy methods sections
  • Citing - How to properly cite microscopy equipment and software

docs.title: Data Presentation
docs.text:
• Include scale bars in all microscopy images
  • Clearly state any image processing steps
  • Provide resolution and imaging parameters
  • Include appropriate controls
  • Use consistent display settings within figure panels

docs.title: Data Availability
docs.text:
• Consider depositing raw data in public repositories
  • Include analysis scripts and workflows
  • Document software versions and parameters
  • Link to protocols and detailed methods

docs.title: Reproducibility
docs.text:
• Document all image acquisition parameters
  • Provide detailed analysis workflows
  • Include statistical methods and sample sizes
  • Share code via GitHub or similar platforms

docs.title: Acknowledgments in Publications
docs.text: When publishing research that used Cell Observatory facilities, proper acknowledgment is important. The format of acknowledgment depends on which equipment and resources were used.

docs.title: Basic Acknowledgment Text
docs.text:
For general use of the facility:

"Part of the work has been performed in the Leiden Cell Observatory (LCO), sponsored by [main grant info - to be added]"

docs.title: Equipment-Specific Acknowledgments
docs.text:
Add the following acknowledgments based on the specific equipment used:

If equipment used Add this acknowledgment [Microscope 1] [Grant/funding information] [Microscope 2] [Grant/funding information]

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Here's how to combine multiple acknowledgments:

"Part of the work has been performed in the Leiden Cell Observatory (LCO). The [specific microscope] was supported by [grant number]. Data management was facilitated through [infrastructure grant]."

docs.title: Required Citations
docs.text:
Always include:

  1. The Cell Observatory facility acknowledgment
  2. Specific equipment grants used

docs.title: Additional Requirements
docs.text:
• Include relevant grant numbers
  • Include technical details of equipment used in methods section

Contact facility staff if you're unsure about which acknowledgments to include in your publication.

docs.title: Writing Methods for Microscopy Experiments
docs.text: This section provides guidelines for writing methods sections in scientific publications for experiments performed at the Leiden Cell Observatory.

docs.title: General Guidelines
docs.text: Content to be added

docs.title: Required Information
docs.text: Content to be added

docs.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
docs.text: Content to be added

docs.title: Data Analysis Documentation
docs.text: Content to be added

docs.title: Example Templates
docs.text: Content to be added

docs.title: Useful resources
docs.text:
Community-developed checklists for publishing images and image analyses

Citation Reminder

Remember to include appropriate citations as described in the Citations section.

Method Writing Tips

  • Include all relevant microscope settings
  • Specify software versions used
  • Document any image processing steps
  • Describe analysis workflows in detail
